clusters.title: AI can forecast your future health – just like the weather
clusters.neutral_headline: AI predicts future health risks, forecasting disease potential

items.title: AI can forecast your future health – just like the weather
items.standfirst: An artificial intelligence model can predict the risk of more than 1,000 diseases, a team of scientists say.
items.content: An artificial intelligence model can predict the risk of more than 1,000 diseases, a team of scientists say.

items.title: New AI tool can predict a person’s risk of more than 1,000 diseases, say experts
items.standfirst: Delphi-2M uses diagnoses, ‘medical events’ and lifestyle factors to create forecasts for next decade and beyondScientists have developed a new artificial intelligence tool that can predict your personal risk of more than 1,000 diseases, and forecast changes in health a decade in advance.The generative AI tool was custom-built by experts from the European Molecular Biology Laboratory (EMBL), the German Cancer Research Centre and the University of Copenhagen, using algorithmic concepts similar to those used in large language models (LLMs). Continue reading...
items.content: Delphi-2M uses diagnoses, ‘medical events’ and lifestyle factors to create forecasts for next decade and beyondScientists have developed a new artificial intelligence tool that can predict your personal risk of more than 1,000 diseases, and forecast changes in health a decade in advance.The generative AI tool was custom-built by experts from the European Molecular Biology Laboratory (EMBL), the German Cancer Research Centre and the University of Copenhagen, using algorithmic concepts similar to those used in large language models (LLMs). Continue reading...

ai_summary: An AI model can predict the risk of over 1,000 diseases, according to scientists.
The Delphi-2M tool uses diagnoses, events, and lifestyle factors for forecasts.
Experts from EMBL, the German Cancer Research Centre, and the University of Copenhagen built the AI.
The AI forecasts health changes a decade in advance.
The tool uses algorithmic concepts similar to large language models.

clusters.title: Air pollution can affect how well we sleep, scientists discover
clusters.neutral_headline: Air pollution linked to sleep quality, according to research

items.title: Air pollution can affect how well we sleep, scientists discover
items.standfirst: Global metastudy finds long-term exposure to pollutants is linked to shorter or lower-quality restAir pollution is affecting how well we sleep, according to the findings of an international evidence review. Dr Junxin Li, of the Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing, who led the review, said: “For years our team has been studying sleep in older adults living in the Baltimore area. Outdoor air quality may change block-by-block and, in some residences, we noticed exhaust fumes from nearby traffic. This led us to a simple but critical question: could the air older adults breathe indoors – as well as just outside their front door – be influencing how well they sleep?”Li’s team searched for studies from around the globe. Focusing on people over 45 years old, they found 25 high quality studies since 2015. These looked at 1.2 million people in six countries including China, India, the US and Germany. Continue reading...
items.content: Global metastudy finds long-term exposure to pollutants is linked to shorter or lower-quality restAir pollution is affecting how well we sleep, according to the findings of an international evidence review. Dr Junxin Li, of the Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing, who led the review, said: “For years our team has been studying sleep in older adults living in the Baltimore area. Outdoor air quality may change block-by-block and, in some residences, we noticed exhaust fumes from nearby traffic. This led us to a simple but critical question: could the air older adults breathe indoors – as well as just outside their front door – be influencing how well they sleep?”Li’s team searched for studies from around the globe. Focusing on people over 45 years old, they found 25 high quality studies since 2015. These looked at 1.2 million people in six countries including China, India, the US and Germany. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Long-term exposure to pollutants is linked to shorter or lower-quality rest.
The international review focused on people over 45 years old.
The study examined 1.2 million people in six countries.
Researchers found 25 high-quality studies since 2015.
Air quality may influence sleep quality, according to the study.

clusters.title: UK doctors guilty of sexual misconduct are not being struck off, research finds
clusters.neutral_headline: UK doctors guilty of sexual misconduct are not being struck off, research finds

items.title: UK doctors guilty of sexual misconduct are not being struck off, research finds
items.standfirst: Analysis reveals 24% of guilty doctors handed suspensions but are allowed to keep working in medicineUK doctors who are guilty of sexual misconduct are not being appropriately sanctioned due to weak disciplinary processes, research reveals.Nearly a quarter (24%) of doctors found guilty of sexual misconduct were handed suspensions but allowed to continue working in medicine, according to analysis of fitness to practice tribunals by the Royal College of Surgeons (RCS). This is despite the regulator, the General Medical Council (GMC), recommending they be struck off the medical register. Continue reading...
items.content: Analysis reveals 24% of guilty doctors handed suspensions but are allowed to keep working in medicineUK doctors who are guilty of sexual misconduct are not being appropriately sanctioned due to weak disciplinary processes, research reveals.Nearly a quarter (24%) of doctors found guilty of sexual misconduct were handed suspensions but allowed to continue working in medicine, according to analysis of fitness to practice tribunals by the Royal College of Surgeons (RCS). This is despite the regulator, the General Medical Council (GMC), recommending they be struck off the medical register. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Analysis reveals 24% of guilty doctors received suspensions, continuing to practice.
The Royal College of Surgeons analyzed fitness to practice tribunals.
The General Medical Council recommended striking off the medical register.
The research indicates weak disciplinary processes for misconduct.
The study highlights concerns about appropriate sanctions for doctors.

clusters.title: CDC panel recommends multiple shots for measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox instead of single vaccine
clusters.neutral_headline: CDC panel recommends multiple shots for measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox instead of single vaccine

items.title: CDC panel recommends multiple shots for measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox instead of single vaccine
items.standfirst: Experts react with concern that increasing the number of vaccinations required will threaten children’s healthA powerful vaccines committee for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) voted on Thursday to change US vaccine policy and start recommending that children receive multiple vaccines to protect against measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox, instead of a single vaccine that can protect against all four diseases.The new recommendations from the panel, the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP), arrived just a day after top former CDC officials said Robert F Kennedy Jr was a threat to US children’s ability to receive vaccines on schedule. The committee’s work typically determines which vaccines are provided free of charge through the US government, shapes state and local laws around vaccine requirements, and influences which vaccines health insurers tend to cover. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts react with concern that increasing the number of vaccinations required will threaten children’s healthA powerful vaccines committee for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) voted on Thursday to change US vaccine policy and start recommending that children receive multiple vaccines to protect against measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox, instead of a single vaccine that can protect against all four diseases.The new recommendations from the panel, the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP), arrived just a day after top former CDC officials said Robert F Kennedy Jr was a threat to US children’s ability to receive vaccines on schedule. The committee’s work typically determines which vaccines are provided free of charge through the US government, shapes state and local laws around vaccine requirements, and influences which vaccines health insurers tend to cover. Continue reading...

items.title: West coast states band together to issue vaccine guidelines after CDC and HHS purge
items.standfirst: California, Oregon, Washington and Hawaii release recommendations in wake of firings at federal health agenciesFour western states are issuing their own joint recommendations for who should receive Covid, flu and RSV vaccines this fall, providing a counterbalance in anticipation of new vaccine guidance from the Trump administration, which has purged prominent scientists from the federal health department and appointed vaccine skeptics and critics to key roles.The new recommendations come as a recently fired director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Susan Monarez, testified to Congress that she feared that under Robert F Kennedy Jr, the Trump-appointed head of the Department of Health and Human Services, there was “a real risk that recommendations could be made restricting access to vaccines for children and others in need, without rigorous scientific review”. Continue reading...
items.content: California, Oregon, Washington and Hawaii release recommendations in wake of firings at federal health agenciesFour western states are issuing their own joint recommendations for who should receive Covid, flu and RSV vaccines this fall, providing a counterbalance in anticipation of new vaccine guidance from the Trump administration, which has purged prominent scientists from the federal health department and appointed vaccine skeptics and critics to key roles.The new recommendations come as a recently fired director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Susan Monarez, testified to Congress that she feared that under Robert F Kennedy Jr, the Trump-appointed head of the Department of Health and Human Services, there was “a real risk that recommendations could be made restricting access to vaccines for children and others in need, without rigorous scientific review”. Continue reading...

items.title: RFK Jr’s actions risk restricting children’s access to vaccines, say ousted CDC officials
items.standfirst: Former officials testify before US Senate, saying the CDC under Kennedy is ‘supporting policies not based in science’RFK Jr and red flags: key moments from ousted CDC director’s testimonyTop former officials at the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) accused Robert F Kennedy Jr of hobbling the country’s ability to respond to outbreaks and disease threats.The two officials testified at a hearing on Wednesday before the Senate Help (Health, Education, Labor and Pensions) committee. Susan Monarez, the CDC director chosen by Kennedy, was fired after less than a month. Debra Houry, chief medical officer at the CDC, resigned after serving under six CDC directors during both Republican and Democratic administrations. Continue reading...
items.content: Former officials testify before US Senate, saying the CDC under Kennedy is ‘supporting policies not based in science’RFK Jr and red flags: key moments from ousted CDC director’s testimonyTop former officials at the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) accused Robert F Kennedy Jr of hobbling the country’s ability to respond to outbreaks and disease threats.The two officials testified at a hearing on Wednesday before the Senate Help (Health, Education, Labor and Pensions) committee. Susan Monarez, the CDC director chosen by Kennedy, was fired after less than a month. Debra Houry, chief medical officer at the CDC, resigned after serving under six CDC directors during both Republican and Democratic administrations. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The CDC panel voted to change US vaccine policy.
The new policy recommends multiple vaccines for measles, mumps, rubella, and chickenpox.
The committee's work influences vaccine recommendations and coverage.
The recommendations come after firings at federal health agencies.
Four western states are issuing their own vaccine recommendations.

clusters.title: Cost of private psychology soars in UK as practitioners turn away clients
clusters.neutral_headline: Private psychology costs increase, practitioners turn away clients

items.title: Cost of private psychology soars in UK as practitioners turn away clients
items.standfirst: Prices have risen by 34% since 2022, with 29% of psychologists refusing new patientsThe cost of seeing private psychologists is soaring and many are so busy they are turning away new clients, research has found.The prices psychologists charge have risen by 34% since 2022 and 12 sessions now cost an average of £1,550, compared with £1,152 just three years ago, according to a survey by myTribe Insurance, which tracks the cost of private medical care.The average cost of a consultation in the UK has risen from £96 in 2022 to £129.20 in 2025.Psychologists in England charge the most (£131) per session and those in Scotland the least (£124).Those in Scotland have the shortest waiting times (16.9 days), and people in Wales the longest (23.8 days). Continue reading...
items.content: Prices have risen by 34% since 2022, with 29% of psychologists refusing new patientsThe cost of seeing private psychologists is soaring and many are so busy they are turning away new clients, research has found.The prices psychologists charge have risen by 34% since 2022 and 12 sessions now cost an average of £1,550, compared with £1,152 just three years ago, according to a survey by myTribe Insurance, which tracks the cost of private medical care.The average cost of a consultation in the UK has risen from £96 in 2022 to £129.20 in 2025.Psychologists in England charge the most (£131) per session and those in Scotland the least (£124).Those in Scotland have the shortest waiting times (16.9 days), and people in Wales the longest (23.8 days). Continue reading...

ai_summary: Prices for private psychology have risen by 34% since 2022.
29% of psychologists are refusing new patients due to high demand.
12 sessions now cost an average of £1,550, up from £1,152 three years ago.
The average consultation cost in the UK has risen to £129.20 in 2025.
Psychologists in England charge the most per session, Scotland the least.

clusters.title: NHS drug pricing is all about the art of the deal | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS drug pricing is all about the art of the deal

items.title: NHS drug pricing is all about the art of the deal | Letter
items.standfirst: Better negotiation with big pharma could ease the process, writes Andrew Dillon, in response to an article by Polly Toynbee about Donald Trump’s complaints about NHS pricingPolly Toynbee describes NHS drug pricing as a “special circle of hell”, and I can vouch for that, but there are ways it can be made better (Who benefits if NHS drug prices soar? Donald Trump and big pharma. Just one more way he’s menacing Britain, 16 September).New drugs are never cheaper than the ones they replace, so if the NHS is going to use them, they need to be better. Most newly licensed drugs do something useful for at least some patients. While a few revolutionise treatment, most edge forward improvements in the quality and length of life, and the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) recommends the great majority of them. Continue reading...
items.content: Better negotiation with big pharma could ease the process, writes Andrew Dillon, in response to an article by Polly Toynbee about Donald Trump’s complaints about NHS pricingPolly Toynbee describes NHS drug pricing as a “special circle of hell”, and I can vouch for that, but there are ways it can be made better (Who benefits if NHS drug prices soar? Donald Trump and big pharma. Just one more way he’s menacing Britain, 16 September).New drugs are never cheaper than the ones they replace, so if the NHS is going to use them, they need to be better. Most newly licensed drugs do something useful for at least some patients. While a few revolutionise treatment, most edge forward improvements in the quality and length of life, and the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) recommends the great majority of them. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses NHS drug pricing and its complexities.
The author suggests better negotiation with big pharma could ease the process.
New drugs are never cheaper than the ones they replace.
The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence recommends most new drugs.

clusters.title: A hi-tech health prediction that I could do without | Brief letters
clusters.neutral_headline: A hi-tech health prediction that I could do without

items.title: A hi-tech health prediction that I could do without | Brief letters
items.standfirst: Worried sick | Waking the dead | Saint George’s flag | Donald Trump’s state visit to BritainThe new artificial intelligence tool that can predict a person’s risk of 1,000 diseases fills me with apprehension (Report, 17 September). If, say, the tool forecasts that I have a 30% chance of suffering from a horrible condition within the next five years, I’m not sure whether that would be good news or bad.Sam WhiteLewes, East Sussex• Bringing the dodo back is interesting (Scientists claim they’ve made ‘pivotal step’ in bringing back the dodo for first time in 300 years, 17 September), but perhaps futile with Homo sapiens’ insistence on destroying the planet. Far better to resurrect Homo neanderthalensis, by all accounts a more cooperative and less aggressive hominid. Patrick CosgroveBucknell, Shropshire Continue reading...
items.content: Worried sick | Waking the dead | Saint George’s flag | Donald Trump’s state visit to BritainThe new artificial intelligence tool that can predict a person’s risk of 1,000 diseases fills me with apprehension (Report, 17 September). If, say, the tool forecasts that I have a 30% chance of suffering from a horrible condition within the next five years, I’m not sure whether that would be good news or bad.Sam WhiteLewes, East Sussex• Bringing the dodo back is interesting (Scientists claim they’ve made ‘pivotal step’ in bringing back the dodo for first time in 300 years, 17 September), but perhaps futile with Homo sapiens’ insistence on destroying the planet. Far better to resurrect Homo neanderthalensis, by all accounts a more cooperative and less aggressive hominid. Patrick CosgroveBucknell, Shropshire Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the apprehension surrounding AI health prediction tools.
The author is concerned about the implications of disease risk forecasts.

clusters.title: Abortion pill providers targeted by new Texas law refuse ‘anticipatory obedience’
clusters.neutral_headline: Texas Law Targets Abortion Pill Providers, Fuels State Abortion Clash

items.title: Abortion pill providers targeted by new Texas law refuse ‘anticipatory obedience’
items.standfirst: Greg Abbott’s latest move fuels clash between US red states and blue-state shield laws protecting abortion careGreg Abbott, the Republican governor of Texas, on Wednesday signed into law a bill that lets people sue anyone suspected of manufacturing, distributing or mailing abortion pills to or from Texas. The first-of-its-kind law is almost certain to dramatically escalate the state-by-state showdown over abortion laws in the post Roe v Wade United States – especially as some out-of-state abortion providers have already vowed that they will continue shipping pills to Texans.“Our mantra as a practice is: ‘No anticipatory obedience’,” said Dr Angel Foster, co-founder of the Massachusetts Medication Abortion Access Project (Map), a Boston-area based group that uses telemedicine to ship abortion pills to patients across the United States. “We will continue to provide care until we are legally unable to do so in Massachusetts.” Continue reading...
items.content: Greg Abbott’s latest move fuels clash between US red states and blue-state shield laws protecting abortion careGreg Abbott, the Republican governor of Texas, on Wednesday signed into law a bill that lets people sue anyone suspected of manufacturing, distributing or mailing abortion pills to or from Texas. The first-of-its-kind law is almost certain to dramatically escalate the state-by-state showdown over abortion laws in the post Roe v Wade United States – especially as some out-of-state abortion providers have already vowed that they will continue shipping pills to Texans.“Our mantra as a practice is: ‘No anticipatory obedience’,” said Dr Angel Foster, co-founder of the Massachusetts Medication Abortion Access Project (Map), a Boston-area based group that uses telemedicine to ship abortion pills to patients across the United States. “We will continue to provide care until we are legally unable to do so in Massachusetts.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Texas law allows lawsuits against those suspected of mailing abortion pills to or from Texas.
Out-of-state abortion providers vow to continue shipping pills to Texans despite the law.
Massachusetts Medication Abortion Access Project will continue providing care until legally unable.
The law is expected to escalate the state-by-state conflict over abortion laws.
The law is the first of its kind in the United States.

clusters.title: One in three GPs in England do not work in NHS, says BMJ study
clusters.neutral_headline: One in three GPs in England do not work in NHS, says BMJ study

items.title: One in three GPs in England do not work in NHS, says BMJ study
items.standfirst: Almost 20,000 family doctors who could work for health service are ‘lost’ to it despite increasing demand for careOne in three GPs in England do not work in the NHS, with increasing numbers seeking to move abroad or becoming a private contractor, deepening patients’ difficulties in getting appointments.The proportion of family doctors who, although qualified, do not provide care through the NHS has risen from 27% in 2015 to 34% last year, according to a study published in the BMJ. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: A BMJ study reveals one in three GPs in England do not work in the NHS.
Increasing numbers of GPs are moving abroad or becoming private contractors.
The proportion of GPs not providing NHS care rose from 27% in 2015 to 34% last year.
This trend deepens patients' difficulties in getting appointments.
Almost 20,000 family doctors are "lost" to the NHS despite rising demand.
